title: Grand Pacific Manchester and The Botanist Didsbury reveal opening dates
text:
Grand Pacific Manchester and The Botanist Didsbury reveal opening dates Diaries out - Manchester's restaurant and bar scene welcomes two big name arrivals soon Share Grand Pineapple cocktail at Grand Pacific Share Get What's On updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Manchester's ever-growing restaurant and bar scene will welcome another two big-name arrivals over the coming months as Grand Pacific opens on King Street and The Botanist branches out to Didsbury. 
The city centre's historic Reform Club will reopen as Grand Pacific on Friday March 17, styled on the grand old colonial hotels of south east Asia. 
Formerly home to the notorious Reform restaurant and latterly Room, the grade II listed building's palatial first floor dining room is being transformed into an all-day drinking and dining den by Living Ventures, who say they want to 'recreate the golden age of high society with a comfortable, relaxed charm [and] great service'. 
Blending exotic flavours with English classics, the food offering will include a classical Sunday lunch with roast beef carved at the table, accompanied by live music from the Grand Pacific Palm Court Group. An indulgent high tea will also be available, with sweet treats from far-flung destinations served alongside specially-blended teas and champagne cocktails. Read More 
The 'tranquil, classic interior' will incorporate many of the building's original features along with palm trees and a 25-seat Long Bar inspired by Raffles Hotel in Singapore, serving up exotic cocktails set to an eclectic soundtrack. Inside the Reform Club before its transformation into Grand Pacific 
Living Ventures CEO Jeremy Roberts said: "We are delighted to bring this beautiful room back to life and echo its glorious past as the home of the historic Manchester Reform Club. 
"Its heritage as a place to relax, eat and drink and just enjoy some of the pleasures of life simply oozes from the walls and it is our privilege and pleasure to let it continue to be what it was always meant to be." Read More Six new Manchester restaurants and bars to try in February 
Meanwhile, bar group The Botanist has also announced the opening date for its 12th branch, which takes over former Wetherspoons pub The Milson Rhodes on Monday April 3. 
The School Lane site, next to burger bar Solita and bistro Hispi, will serve a range of botanical cocktails and gins, as well as a wide selection of world and local beers, alongside a food menu featuring hanging kebabs, rotisserie meats and deli platters. How it could look: The Botanist in Knutsford (Photo: Gareth Lowe) 
It will also host live music every evening as well as lazy Sunday afternoon sessions with what bosses promise will be 'a real home-from-home atmosphere' when it opens in spring 2017. 
General manager Danny Leach, who joins the team from The Oast House in Spinningfields, said: “We are very proud to announce the official opening date to the residents and visitors of Didsbury Village, and invite people in to see the stunning transformation of the space. 
“We will be open for coffees through to cocktails with live music and our much-loved food menu from April 3, so come in and say hello." Read More
